title: Moxie Shirt 2007
body:
Over the last year and a half, we've heard a lot of requests from our customers. "You need chairs that aren't broken!" New chairs are being installed on the 20th and 21st. "I can't find your building!" A big neon sign will be going up in the next few months. "When are you getting new shirts?" Well, after nearly a year and a half, I'm happy to announce that the new Moxie shirts will be available one week from tomorrow (Friday, December 15th). Just in time for the holidays! WOO HOO! So, without further ado, here's the new Moxie shirt for 2007:



In case you don't have super vision, here's a close up of the front:



and the back:



Now, you're probably thinking to yourself, "what the hell?!" Let me explain. Back when we first opened, one of regular customers took a shirt and created the first Moxie Tally Shirt. After each movie he saw here, he'd make a mark on the front, and write the name of the film on the back. Nearly one year and three months later, his shirt is almost completely full, and it looks really cool. His shirt was the inspiration for our newest design. Feel free to fill in the box on the back however you like. You can put hatch mark, stars, little popcorn kernels... whatever you want to use to denote how many films you've seen at The Moxie.



Or, if you don't get a chance to see many movies here, you can go the other direction and fill up space by writing out the titles.



If you don't feel like writing on your shirt at all, you can always use the box on the back to screen your own independent movies. After all, our screen isn't much bigger than the box on an XL shirt.



So, there it is: Moxie Shirt 2007. Each one has the potential to be completely different than all the rest, which is why I think they're super, SUPER cool. We're selling them for $18 each, or $20 if you want a shirt AND a sharpie (for which to make your marks with). Again, they'll be ready to pick up next Friday, but I'm sure if you flash us a friendly smile, we'd be happy to sell you one in advance. Ok, it's time to open. WOO HOO!!!!!!!!!
author: Dan

Oh, and smiling. Looking happy in a picture is useful, because it portrays you in a good light for years to come. Also of note, I never said that as a silly pose it (Charlie's Angels pose) was useless, I said as a pose it was useless. There are many poses that are useful, as I mentioned in my example, but few silly poses are useful. Your inference, Max, was both assumptive and illogical.

Try again later.

Posted By: dan
Posted By: nate3) COOL POSES -Charlie's Angels gun holding pose, or Superman.

comments.author: nate
comments.body: Marriage proposals would most definitely qualify as a #2 category pic.

comments.author: nate
comments.body:
I will grant you that the Superman pics are a worthy addition.

It seems that there are 3 categories of worthy Moxie pics:

1) LOCATION - i.e., easily identifiable landmarks, preferably iconic such as recognizable monuments, buildings, or natural features like the Grand Canyon. Failing that, common but fun-looking locations will suffice: beaches, carnivals, or drunken weddings.

2) UNIQUE SITUATIONS - Maybe you are dolled up with the girls in your Friday night finest and are about to head out dancing. Maybe you just got done rock climbing and still have your harness on. Maybe you are holding your new puppy. If any of these are you, slap on that Moxie shirt and take a picture!!

3) COOL POSES - Charlie's Angels gun holding pose, or Superman.

Well, so far Max has the record for total number of pictures. But many of his are at the same general location... even on the same day, so it's not really fair.
And mundane locations, such as Anytown Restaurant, are not as good either.

I, on the other hand, have such unique contributions as the Statue of Liberty and skydiving.*

*not really skydiving. More like on the ground after skydiving. But you try taking a picture of yourself at arm's length while in freefall, with your jumpsuit unzipped in order to expose the shirt. Not easy my friend. Not easy.
